metadata.title: Two-dimensional Pd-based nanomaterials for bioapplications

sections.text:
Noble metal nanomaterials have been extensively explored in cancer diagnostic and therapeutic applications owing to their unique physical and chemical properties, such as facile synthesis, straightforward surface functionalization, strong photothermal effect, and excellent biocompatibility. Herein, we summarize the recent development of two-dimensional (2D) Pd-based nanomaterials and their applications in cancer diagnosis and therapy. Different synthetic strategies for Pd nanosheets and the related nanostructures, including Pd@Au, Pd@Ag nanoplates and mesocrystalline Pd nanocorolla, are first discussed. Together with their unique properties, the potential bioapplications of these 2D Pd nanomaterials are then demonstrated. With strong absorption in near-infrared (NIR) region, these nanomaterials have great potentials in cancer photothermal therapy (PTT). They also readily act as contrast agents in photoacoustic (PA) imaging or X-ray computed tomography (CT) to achieve imageguided cancer therapy. Moreover, significant efforts have been devoted to studying
the combination of PTT and other treatment modalities (e.g., chemotherapy or photodynamic therapy) based on Pd nanomaterials. The remarkable synergistic or collaborative effects to achieve better therapeutic efficacy are discussed as well. Additionally, the biosafety of 2D Pd-based nanomaterials in vitro and in vivo was evaluated. Finally, challenges for the applications of Pd-based nanomaterials in cancer diagnosis and therapy, and future research prospects are highlighted.
Keywords 2D nanomaterials · Palladium · Optical properties · Bioimaging · Photothermal therapy · Combination therapy

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
With the development of nanotechnology, the application of nanomaterials for drug delivery, cancer diagnosis and therapy has attracted great attention [1]. Especially two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials with unique properties originated from their atomically thin thickness and 2D morphology features have been extensively studied in recent years [2-8]. For example, graphene and some transition metal dichalcogenides (e.g., MoS2 and Bi2Se3) with high surface area, strong near-infrared (NIR) light absorption and good biocompatibility have been applied to photothermal therapy and other biomedical fields [2-4, 6, 7].
Photothermal therapy (PTT), in which light energy is converted into thermal energy by light-absorbing agents for destroying cancer cells, has recently emerged as a new candidate technique for cancer treatment [9-15]. In particular, NIR laser-induced PTT has attracted increasing attention because of the deep tissue penetrating nature of NIR irradiation [16, 17]. A prerequisite for the development of NIR laser-induced PTT is to acquire biocompatible and efficient photothermal agents. Currently several types of NIR absorbing photothermal agents, including the organic compounds (e.g., indocyanine green (ICG) dye) [18-21], carbon-based nanomaterials (e.g., graphene oxide (GO) and carbon nanotubes) [22-26], metal nanostructures (e.g., Au or Pdbased nanomaterials) [27-38], copper chalcogenide semiconductors [39-42] and transition metal dichalcogenides mentioned above [6, 7], have been explored for photothermal ablation of cancer. Despite intense research interest in using these nanomaterials for PTT, several challenges still remain. For instance, the difficulty in adjusting the shape and size of NIR-absorbing nanomaterials makes systematical
investigation of their bio-behaviors impossible and thus limits their clinical applications [33, 43]. Therefore, the development of NIR photothermal agents with well-defined morphologies and sizes, as well as good photothermal properties for cancer therapy, has aroused great research interest.
Lately, two-dimensional (2D) Pd nanosheets (NSs) have been regarded as a new kind of promising photothermal agents. They exhibit the following unique features: (1) the diameter of uniform Pd NSs is highly tunable in a wide range from sub-5 nm to 120 nm with fixed thickness, 1.8 nm, by changing the synthetic conditions. Moreover, other noble metals, such as Au and Ag, can be readily grown on the surface of Pd NSs to prepare 2D core-shell noble metal nanoplates with various thicknesses. By contrast, it is extremely challenging to synthesize other 2D nanostructures (e.g., like graphene, Bi2Se3 and MoS2) with well-defined thickness and diameter. (2) 2D Pd-based nanomaterials with different sizes exhibit strong absorption in the NIR region and also give high photothermal conversion efficiency. For example, a photothermal conversion efficiency of 52.0% at 808 nm was observed on
Pd NSs with diameter of ∼4.4 nm [38]. (3) 2D nanomaterials based on Pd have high
photothermal stability upon NIR irradiation. For instance, the sheet-like structure of Pd@Ag nanoplates as well as their surface plasmon resonance (SPR) absorption in NIR region were well retained after exposure to 808-nm laser at 2 W for 30 min, whereas silver nanoprisms were severely distorted under the same irradiation [36]. (4) Besides their function as effective photothermal contrast agents for PTT and PTTbased combined therapy, Pd-based 2D nanomaterials readily act as contrast agents for cancer PA or CT imaging. (5) They typically exhibit excellent biocompability both in vitro and in vivo. Due to these remarkable properties, the bioapplications of 2D Pdbased nanomaterials have been widely explored since they were first synthesized by our group [5] in 2011.
In this review, we will first summarize the synthesis and optical properties of Pdbased 2D nanomaterials. Recent advances of the 2D Pd-based nanomaterials in cancer theranostics including imaging, PTT and PTT-based combined therapy are then discussed. Moreover, the biosafety of these nanomaterials is assessed. Finally, perspectives on major challenges and future opportunities of 2D nanomaterials based on Pd are underlined.

2.2 Synthesis of Pd@M (M=Au and Ag) bimetallic nanoplates
Noble metals, including Au and Ag, are readily epitaxially deposited on the surface of Pd NSs to form the well-defined core-shell Pd@M nanostructures (Fig. 1a) [36, 45, 47]. Typically, uniform hexagonal Pd NSs were first synthesized and used as seeds for the growth of Au or Ag thereon to produce the core-shell nanoplates. The growth of Au or Ag on Pd NSs was achieved by chemically reducing AuPPh3Cl with hydrazine hydrate in DMF (Fig. 1c) [45] or reducing AgNO3 with formaldehyde [36] or H2 [47] in an aqueous solution respectively (Fig. 1d). The thickness of Au or Ag layer on Pd NSs can be fine-tuned by changing the amount of Au or Ag precursor. It should be noted that the growth of Ag on Pd NSs proceeded from the uniform deposition of Ag overlayer on Pd NSs. By contrast, the coating of Au on Pd NSs grew gradually from the edges towards the center.

sections.heading: 2.3 Synthesis of mesocrystalline Pd nanocorolla
sections.text:
The corolla-like Pd mesocrystallites composed of interconnected ultrathin Pd NSs
(∼1.8 nm) were synthesized by an etching growth strategy under CO confinement (Fig. 1a, e) [46]. The preparation procedure of Pd nanocorolla is similar to that of Pd NSs except the addition of FeCl3 as etching agent. The co-presence of CO and Fe 3+ was critical to the synthesis of the branched corolla-like Pd mesocrystallites. While the existence of CO makes it possible for anisotropic growth of the 1.8 nm-thick Pd NSs as branches, Fe 3+ etches the Pd seeds at the early reaction stage, resulting in the formation of the branched structure.

sections.heading: 3 Optical properties of 2D Pd-based nanomaterials
sections.text:
A common remarkable property of these Pd-based 2D nanomaterials is that they exhibit size- or thickness-dependent surface plasmon resonance (SPR) absorption. For instance, with the increase of edge length from 21 to 27, 41 and 51 nm, the SPR peak of the Pd NSs was red-shifted from 826 to 992, and from 1,045 to 1,068 nm, respectively (Fig. 2a) [5, 37]. What is more, the maximum optical absorption of
Pd@Ag nanoplates was blue-shifted from 971 nm to 812, 710, 602, 529 and 477 nm as the thickness of Pd@Ag nanoplates raised from 3.5 to 5.4, 6.9, 14.1, and 19.8 nm, respectively (Fig. 2b) [36, 37]. Similarly, different sizes of Pd@Au nanoplates also showed tunable optical spectra in NIR region [45].
The ultrathin sheet-like feature with the thickness fixed at ∼1.8 nm is essential to
the unique SPR property of Pd NSs, which has been confirmed by the calculation of extinction spectra using the discrete dipole approximation (DDA) method. Pd NSs exhibited strong absorption in the NIR region. The extinction coefficient of 41 nm Pd NSs was measured to be 4.1×10 9 L/(mol cm) at 1,045 nm, comparable to that of Au nanorods. Unlike pure Au or Ag nanostructures that display NIR absorption, Pd NSs showed an excellent stability upon NIR laser irradiation [48]. Significantly enhanced stability under laser irradiation was also observed for Pd@Ag nanoplates (Fig. 2c) compared to pure Ag nanoprisms which was destroyed under the same irradiation (Fig. 2d) [36, 37].

sections.heading: 4 Application of 2D Pd-based nanomaterials in imaging and therapy
sections.text:
4.1 Contrast agents for imaging
Photoacoustic (PA) imaging, as a noninvasive imaging modality, has recently attracted increasing interests in biomedical fields [49-53]. In this technique, endogenous or exogenous PA contrast agents can absorb pulsed laser energy and convert it into heat, resulting in thermal expansion of the air that surrounds the contrast agents and creates acoustic waves for imaging [50, 51]. Currently, due to the weak optical absorption of most endogenous PA contrast agents, tremendous effort has been devoted to the development of exogenous PA imaging agents for better contrast effect and detection depth. Nanomaterials with NIR absorption such as organic dye-based nanoparticles, polymer-based nanoparticles, carbon-based nanomaterials and metallic nanomaterials have great potential as exogenous contrast agents for PA imaging [49-58]. Among them, Au nanostructures have been extensively investigated [51, 56], however, the anisotropic gold nanostructures can be easily destroyed by laser irradiation. On the other hand, 2D Pd-based nanomaterials are ideal candidates as a new class of exogenous PA contrast agents for PA imaging because of their strong absorption in NIR region, high photothermal stability, and good tumor accumulation capability. Nie et al. [48] have demonstrated the application of Pd NSs as contrast agents for in vivo PA imaging. After intravenous administration of Pd NSs into tumor-bearing mice, significant and long-lasting PA contrast-enhanced signals in tumor sites were obtained under 790 nm laser irradiation (4 mJ/cm2). By contrast, the PBS-injected mice only manifested the PA signals of tumor skin owing to the low absorption contrast of tumor. It is worth noting that Pd NSs showed good biocompatibility both in cells and mice. Co-culture cells with Pd NSs at a relative high concentration didn’t affect the cell viability. Moreover the histological examination of mice injected with Pd NSs for 7 days did not show obvious side effect either. In a further investigation from our group, bimetallic Pd@Au-PEG nanoplates were also successfully used as a PA contrast agent to achieve high-quality imaging of tumor sites (Fig. 3a) [45].
X-ray computed tomography (CT) is one of the most frequently used diagnostic tools in hospitals [59, 60]. Because of their high X-ray absorption, good biocompatibility as well as easy surface functionalization [60], Au nanoparticles have been extensively investigated as CT contrast agents. The application of the bimetallic Pd@Au-PEG nanoplates as CT contrast agent was also assessed. It was found that the intensity of the CT signal increased with the increasing concentration of Au and the tumor site showed an obvious enhancement with a significantly higher CT value after 24 h injection of Pd@Au-PEG nanoplates (Fig. 3b) [45].
Besides the application of inherent nature of Pd-based nanomaterials, surface modification with other imaging agents provided us more opportunities to understand their in vivo behaviors. For instance, by conjugating Gd chelates on the surface of Pd NSs, the real-time in vivo distribution of Pd NSs was monitored [61].

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Photothermal therapy (PTT)
sections.text:
As mentioned above, 2D Pd-based nanomaterials exhibited great potential in PTT because of their strong NIR absorption and excellent photothermal stability. In 2011, our group [5] first reported the application of Pd NSs in cancer PTT. It was found that the temperature of 1 mL 27 µg/mL Pd NSs aqueous solution could rise from 28.0 to
48.7 ºC after 10 min under 808 nm laser irradiation with a power density of 1 W/cm2. By incubating liver cancer cells with polyethyleneimine-modified Pd NSs for 12 h, ∼100% of the cells were killed after 5 min of laser irradiation (808 nm, 1.4 W/cm 2 ).
The ultrathin feature of Pd NSs is unique, but weakens their cellular uptake efficiency when used in PTT. To increase the uptake efficacy of Pd NSs, silica coating was employed to increase the thickness of Pd NSs, and amino groups were also modified on the surface of silica [62]. A 13-fold increase of the cellular uptake of Pd NSs was achieved compared to unmodified Pd NSs. As a result, the photothermal cell-killing efficacy was significantly improved. Almost 100% of the cells incubated with Pd@Silica-NH2 were killed after 2 min irradiation, while only half of the cells were killed for unmodified Pd NSs.
The first application of Pd NSs in in vivo PTT appeared in 2014 [38]. Ultra-small Pd NSs about 4.4 nm in diameter were successfully synthesized and modified with reduced glutathione (GSH). Compared with large Pd NSs, ultra-small Pd NSs showed higher photothermal conversion efficiency, and the in vivo behaviors of Pd-GSH were well investigated on tumor-bearing mice after intravenous injection (Fig. 4). Compared with unmodified Pd NSs, Pd NSs modified with glutathione exhibited a remarkable longer blood circulation. Their accumulation in tumor was also increased.
With the use of glutathione-modified Pd NSs, upon 808 nm laser irradiation, tumors were completely ablated. Together with their excellent photothermal conversion efficiency at NIR region, their high tumor accumulation performance makes these ultrasmall Pd NSs with great potentials for application in photothermal cancer therapy.
Core-shell bimetallic Pd@Ag, Pd@Au nanoplates and mesocrystalline Pd nanocorolla have also been used in in vitro and in vivo cancer PTT [36, 45, 47, 63- 65]. We systemically evaluated the in vivo NIR PTT efficacy of Pd@Au nanoplates
with a mean diameter of ∼30 nm and an average thickness of ∼4 nm. After surface modification with PEG-SH, the as-prepared Pd@Au-PEG nanoplates were intravenously injected into 4T1 tumor-bearing Balb/c mice. It was surprising that the
accumulation of Pd@Au-PEG nanoplates in tumor sites was able to achieve ∼79%
ID/g at 24 h post injection. It was demonstrated that the surface PEGylation and the unique two-dimensional structural feature of Pd@Au nanoplates might contribute to their enhanced passive accumulation in tumor sites. As a result of the high accumulation, PTT was carried out at a lower 808 nm laser power density of 0.5 W/cm 2 . The tumors were completely destroyed after 4-min irradiation, and no tumor regrowth was observed over a course of 60 d [45]. Moreover, as compared to singledomain Pd NSs, the mesocrystalline Pd nanocorolla also exhibited higher cancer cells killing efficiency due to the increased apparent thickness that allowed them to be taken up by cells more easily than the ultrathin Pd NSs [47].
Overall, the unique optical properties, high photothermal conversion efficiency and stability, along with the excellent biocompatibility of Pd-based 2D nanomaterials make them potential candidate in cancer PTT, which has been demonstrated by in vitro and in vivo studies.

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Combination therapy of cancer
sections.text:
Although significant progress has been made in the NIR PTT, several disadvantages still limit their potential clinical application [29, 66]. For example, the small spot size produced by laser restricts the therapeutic area of cancer tissue. Relatively high laser power (for instance, 2–4 W/cm2 for gold nanomaterials) is often
used for obtaining sufficient heat to kill cancer cells [67, 68]. Owing to their low-level renal clearance and high accumulation in some reticuloendothelial system (RES)
organs (e.g., liver, spleen) after systematic administration, NIR photothermal nanomaterials may induce potential toxicity [69].
To overcome the limitations of currently available NIR photothermal therapeutic systems as well as take advantages of different treatment modalities, combination therapy has emerged in recent years [70-76]. Compared with single treatment, combined therapy exhibits remarkable synergistic or collaborative effect, and conquers the defect of single treatment mode, therefore can achieve better therapeutic efficacy [72, 75]. Here, we summarized the combination therapy applications of 2D Pd-based nanomaterials in PTT-chemotherapy [64, 65, 77, 78] and PTTphotodynamic therapy (PDT) [63, 79, 80].

sections.heading: 4.2.2.1 PTT-chemotherapy combined therapy
sections.text:
Current clinical treatment investigation has shown that hyperthermia can promote the delivery of drug into tumor [81-83], resulting in additionally enhanced anticancer effect. Like most nanocarriers, 2D Pd-based nanomaterials can also serve as drug delivery platform due to their large surface area, good biocompatibility and facile surface-functionalization. Moreover, the application of laser irradiation not only triggers the release of drug molecules in a controllable manner, but also improves the cell-killing efficiency. Consequently, the integration of PTT and chemotherapy on 2D Pd-based nanomaterials should achieve good synergistic effects.
Fang et al. [64] developed novel mesoporous silica-coated Pd@Ag nanoplates (Pd@Ag@sSiO2@mSiO2-DOX) as a multifunctional therapeutic system (Fig. 5). In the synthesized composite, bimetallic Pd@Ag nanoplate core can effectively convert the absorbed NIR light energy into heat, and the outer mesoporous SiO2 shell provides high surface area for anticancer drug DOX loading. Moreover, DOX molecules are bound to the mesoporous shell through coordination bonds that are sensitive to pH and heat. Thus, the release of DOX from the core-shell delivery vehicles into cancer cells can be triggered by the acidic pH in endosome and NIR laser. As expected, the release of DOX from Pd@Ag@sSiO2@mSiO2-DOX showed pH-dependent manner and the exposure of carrier to 808 nm laser irradiation (1 W) significantly increased the release rate of DOX. Cytotoxicity assay indicated that the cell-killing efficacy for the combination of Pd@Ag@sSiO2@mSiO2-DOX and laser irradiation was higher than the total of chemotherapy by DOX-loaded particles and
photothermal therapy by Pd@Ag@sSiO2@mSiO2 without DOX, showing an outstanding synergistic effect of chemotherapy and photothermal treatment.
Another multifunctional nanosystem integrating PTT and chemotherapy based on 2D Pd-based nanomaterials was also reported by Tang et al. [78]. In this system,
DOX was directly loaded on the surface of ∼4.4 nm small Pd NSs through Pd-N coordination bonding. Then Pd-DOX was modified by reduced glutathione (GSH). Tissue distribution measured by ICP-MS demonstrated that Pd–DOX–GSH accumulated in tumors higher than Pd-GSH after 24 h post injection, indicating that DOX could enhance the accumulation of Pd-GSH nanomaterials in tumors. In vivo experimental results showed that mice treated with Pd-DOX-GSH and laser irradiation (the combination of chemotherapy and PTT) resulted in better therapeutic effects than those treated with Pd-GSH (PTT) or Pd-DOX-GSH (chemotherapy) alone. The synergistic effect yielded effective anticancer therapy with both lower chemical drug doses and lower NIR laser power. More importantly, Pd-DOX–GSH hybrid nanoparticles could be cleared from the body through the renal system into the urine because of their small size.

sections.heading: 4.2.2.2 PTT-photodynamic combined therapy
sections.text:
Photodynamic therapy (PDT) is another light-based technique for cancer therapy [84, 85]. In this technique, photosensitizer (PS) molecules were first irradiated by a suitable wavelength laser, then the activated PS interacts with molecular oxygen to
generate reactive oxygen species to destroy cancer cells irreversibly [84, 85]. However, the application of many PSs in clinic has been impeded by their hydrophobicity and easy aggregation in aqueous solution that greatly reduced PDT efficacy. To overcome the drawbacks and improve the PDT therapeutic efficiency, different strategies, such as loading PSs on various nanocarriers [75, 86-88] and the combination of PDT with other treatment modalities (e.g., chemotherapy, PTT) have been developed [75]. By utilizing some near-infrared absorption photothermal nanomaterials, such as Au and carbon nanostructures, as the carriers of PSs, high synergistic therapeutic effect has been achieved by the combination of PDT and PTT [75].
Recently, we developed mesoporous silica-coated Pd@Ag nanoparticles (Pd@Ag@mSiO2) as an excellent nanoplatform for PS delivery [63]. In this architecture, photosensitizer chlorin e6 (Ce6) were covalently conjugated to the mesoporous shell, preventing them from being degraded or prematurely released into the systemic circulation. The prepared Pd@Ag@mSiO2-Ce6 nanoparticles displayed good water solubility as well as high efficiency in photo-generating cytotoxic singlet oxygen. More importantly, the good photothermal effects of Pd@Ag nanoplates under NIR irradiation could be utilized to enhance the cell uptake of Ce6. Using confocal fluorescence imaging, brighter fluorescence was observed after laser irradiation inside the cells than that without irradiation, indicating more nanoparticles were taken up by the cells. Flow cytometry experiments further confirmed that 808 nm laser irradiation can increase the fluorescence of Ce6 1.3 times greater than the cells incubation with nanoparticles without irradiation. These results indicated that moderate temperature rise caused by Pd@Ag@mSiO2-Ce6 nanoparticles under NIR light irradiation could increase cell membrane permeability and led to the improved cellular uptake of nanoparticles, greatly enhancing the toxicity of nanoparticles and causing more cell death than only PDT. The PTT/PDT combined therapy effects were also demonstrated in vivo with satisfactory results.
Although excellent therapeutic indexes have been achieved via PTT/PDT synergistic effects in most of the studies, the use of two different wavelength lasers to excite PDT and PTT separately will complicate the treatment process due to the absorption mismatch of photothermal agents and PSs at NIR region [33, 89].
To perform PTT/PDT simultaneous treatments upon a single laser, we prepared Ce6-functionalized Pd NSs (Pd-PEI-Ce6) [79]. To synthesize Pd-PEI-Ce6, Ce6 was
firstly conjugated to polyethylenimine (PEI), then the prepared Ce6-PEI was loaded onto small Pd NSs via electrostatic and coordination interaction (Fig. 6a). Pd-PEI-Ce6 had following merits: (1) The maximum absorption wavelength of small Pd NSs and Ce6 was about 660 nm in the NIR region. Laser at this wavelength alone should excite PDT and PTT simultaneously, simplifying the experimental procedure. (2) Excellent singlet oxygen generation capacity, high photothermal conversion efficiency and good biocompatibility, would benefit the in vivo treatment application. With these advantages, the photothermal-photodynamic combination therapy was successfully performed both in vitro and in vivo, demonstrating greater treatment effects than PTT using Pd NSs or PDT using Ce6 alone (Fig. 6b, c). This work highlights the potential of Pd NSs for multimode cancer therapies.
Fig. 6 (Color online) (a) Fabrication and PTT/PDT combined treatment applications of Pd-PEI-Ce6 nanocomposite. (b) Fluorescence images of HeLa cells incubated with Ce6, Pd-PEI nanosheets and Pd-PEI-Ce6 for 12 h under irradiation of 660 nm laser (0.5 W/cm2) for 5 min. The cells were stained with propidium iodide (PI). (c) Relative tumor volume of S180 tumors in different groups of mice upon treatment with 660 nm laser (0.5 W/cm2) for 5 min. sections.heading: 5 Biosafety of 2D Pd-based nanomaterials
sections.text:
Although 2D nanomaterials have demonstrated wide application prospects in nanomedicine, their biosafety assessments, including pharmacokinetics, biodistribution, biodegradation, excretion and potential toxicity et al, are still in infancy and require further investigation [3]. Pd-based 2D nanomaterials, with welldefined shape and controlled size, can be used as a model system to systematically study the biosafety of 2D nanomaterials. Based on this, we conducted a series of work in cells and animal modes [5, 36, 38, 45, 47, 62-65, 77-80, 90, 91]. No obvious toxicity was observed in vitro and in vivo levels, indicating good biocompatibility of
these 2D Pd-based nanomaterials.
For clinical applications, the nanomaterial-based diagnostic or therapeutic agents should be effectively degraded or eliminated out of body after finishing their functions [92-95] to decrease the likelihood of unintended acute or chronic toxicity [93]. Noble metal nanomaterials are typically difficult to be degraded in vivo. However, we have found that GSH-modified small Pd NSs (∼4.4 nm in diameter)
were clearable from body through the renal excretion route into urine [38]. In this case, both small sizes and GSH coating contributed to the gradual clearance of PdGSH from body. Considering the function of GSH, we further tested the clearance effects of GSH on different surface-modified small Pd NSs (e.g., Pd-PVP, PdPEG(SH)). It was found that the injection of GSH solution effectively increased the clearance of different surface-modified Pd NSs (Fig. 7) [90]. In addition, blood biochemistry and histological examinations also indicated that small Pd NSs did not induce appreciable toxicity to the treated mice. These observations not only suggest that small Pd NSs have relatively high biosafety and hold great potentials for clinical theranostic application, but also provide a new method for promoting the metabolism of other nanoparticles from body. More recently, we systematically investigated the influence of surface modifications on the in vivo behaviors of small Pd NSs [91]. Among the studied coating molecules (i.e., carboxymethyl chitosan, PEG-NH2, PEGSH and dihydrolipoic acid-zwitterion), PEG-SH-coated Pd NSs have the longest blood circulation half-life and also the highest accumulation in tumor. Moreover, Pd NSs with different sizes (i.e., 5, 13, 30, and 80 nm) were also assessed recently for their size-dependent biosafety, such as biodistribution, toxicity and genomic gene expression profiles. Results indicated that size had an important influence on the biological behaviors of Pd NSs [96]. These studies are expected to promote the applications of 2D Pd-based and other nanomaterials in nanomedicines.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and prospects
sections.text:
As an important branch of noble metal nanostructures, 2D Pd-based nanomaterials have recently attracted increasing interests for applications in biomedical field. We summarized in this review the synthesis, properties, biosafety and applications of these 2D Pd-based nanomaterials for cancer imaging, photothermal therapy, and combination therapy. These Pd-based 2D nanomaterials with well-defined shapes and controlled sizes show excellent photothermal conversion efficiency and also photothermal stability, making them as excellent NIR agents for cancer PTT. Based on their large surface area, anticancer drugs or photosensitizers are readily loaded onto these Pd nanomaterials to offer the combination of PTT/chemotherapy and PTT/PDT with enhanced therapeutic effects. In addition, due to their strong absorption in NIR region, these Pd-based nanomaterials can realize imaging (e.g., PA, CT)-guided PTT for cancer treatment.
Although considerable research progresses have been made on the applications of Pd-based 2D nanomaterials in bioimaging and cancer therapy, the following aspects are still needed to be further explored for promoting the clinical translation of these 2D nanosystems:
(1) As demonstrated in our previous work, the sizes and surface coatings have important influences on the biological behaviors and treatment outcomes of 2D Pdbased nanomaterials [38, 90, 91]. To further improve the treatment efficacy as well as biosafety of 2D Pd-based nanomaterials in nanomedicine, it is highly desire to systematically investigate deeply the effects of other factors, including shapes,
composition, charge, thickness and so on, on the in vivo behaviors of Pd-based nanomaterials.
(2) To further expand the applications of Pd-based 2D nanomaterials in nanomedicines, new theranostic functionalities based on these materials should be explored. More imaging and therapeutic modalities, such as radioactive iodine-based SPECT/CT imaging and radiotherapy, can be integrated into these 2D materials to achieve multimode imaging-guided therapy as well as enhanced therapeutic efficacies.
(3) Considering the accumulation of 2D Pd-based nanomaterials in tumors mainly depends on the passive targeting (EPR effects) in most previous work, some targeting molecules (e.g., antibodies, nucleic acid aptamers, small targeting biomolecules) may be modified on the surface of these nanomaterials to further improve their accumulation in tumors via active targeting.
(4) So far, research results indicated that Pd-based nanomaterials had no obvious toxic effects on either cultured cells or living animals for a short term. The potential long-term in vivo toxicities of Pd-based nanomaterials should be systematically evaluated before their future clinical applications.
(5) Pd-based nanomaterials have exhibited good biocompatibility and therapeutic effects in mouse tumor models. In order to push their clinical translational applications, the biological behaviors of 2D Pd-based nanomaterials in more tumor model systems (e.g., on rat, rabbit) should be further explored.
We hope this review will encourage the development of other 2D nanomaterials for
clinical applications.

metadata.abstractText: Noble metal nanomaterials have been extensively explored in cancer diagnostic and therapeutic applications owing to their unique physical and chemical properties, such as facile synthesis, straightforward surface functionalization, strong photothermal effect, and excellent biocompatibility. Herein, we summarize the recent development of two-dimensional (2D) Pd-based nanomaterials and their applications in cancer diagnosis and therapy. Different synthetic strategies for Pd nanosheets and the related nanostructures, including Pd@Au, Pd@Ag nanoplates and mesocrystalline Pd nanocorolla, are first discussed. Together with their unique properties, the potential bioapplications of these 2D Pd nanomaterials are then demonstrated. With strong absorption in near-infrared (NIR) region, these nanomaterials have great potentials in cancer photothermal therapy (PTT). They also readily act as contrast agents in photoacoustic (PA) imaging or X-ray computed tomography (CT) to achieve imageguided cancer therapy. Moreover, significant efforts have been devoted to studying the combination of PTT and other treatment modalities (e.g., chemotherapy or photodynamic therapy) based on Pd nanomaterials. The remarkable synergistic or collaborative effects to achieve better therapeutic efficacy are discussed as well. Additionally, the biosafety of 2D Pd-based nanomaterials in vitro and in vivo was evaluated. Finally, challenges for the applications of Pd-based nanomaterials in cancer diagnosis and therapy, and future research prospects are highlighted.
